item.name: 1830: The Game of Railroads and Robber Barons
1860: Railways on the Isle of Wight
1861: The Railways of the Russian Empire
221B Baker Street: The Master Detective Game
25 Words or Less
item.comment: This game works well with parties. I'd say it is at the harder end of games for parties, as there is considerable concentration required, so I get this one out before everyone has had too much to drink. Very clever design, with bidding, presssure against the timer and the number of words you can use. Recommended for parties of 6 or more people.

item.name: 7 Wonders
item.comment: Speedy game and enjoyable. Plauys with larger numbers without affecting time scale, which is good. Great graphics and easy to play, but deeper than you realise.

item.name: Ace of Aces: Handy Rotary Series
Ad Astra
item.comment: First game and an early valuation. Resource acquisition seems to drive the speed of the game so is slow at the beginning and faster later on. It will be interesting to see how much learning takes place to allow other strategies in later games and how much faster the game coudl be. My first game featured a low number of scoring cards played, so there was no gradual accumulation of points. Rather we had large numbers of points during the last quarter of the game.

item.name: Aeroplanes: Aviation Ascendant
item.comment:
First two games (3 and 5 player) showed that the game works well at ends of the player range. The game plays exceptionally good. The decisions are easy to see but hard to make. O you expand Europe or move to longer distance? To some extent this depends on the passengers and so each game will be different. The aeroplane cards are beautiful and that system works well too. Cheaper or more expensive planes? Ones with more airport capacity or less?
Typical interesting and engaging Wallace game.

item.name: Age of Empires III: The Age of Discovery
Agricola: All Creatures Big and Small
Air War: Modern Tactical Air Combat
Airlines Europe
item.comment: Streamlined for 2011 and feeling so much better for it.

item.name: Alchemist
item.comment: The game easily fits in 30 minutes, which is good. It has more decisions in it than many other potion mixing games and though the strategies are not deep there is enough in it to get more game table time.

item.name: Alchymia: La Quête du Cristal Noir
Anno 1503
item.comment: Very enjoyable game that has several ways to win. All the systems work and are easy to remember. Downtime is low as you can plan what you would like to do.

item.name: Apocalypse: The Game of Nuclear Devastation
Aquädukt
item.comment: Quick turns. Limited options, but sufficent options to consider how the game may pan out in the next 2 turns, and delightfully quick.

item.name: Auf den Spuren von Marco Polo
Ausgebremst
item.comment: Sensational racing game with a great mix of laughs, skill and the non players winning. Many combinations of board add game value, while the selection of cards for your car at the beginning of the game is novel, clever and works. Now a default game of choice for 45 minutes at the conclusion of an evening's gaming.

item.name: Automania: The Game of the Motor Giants
Automobile
item.comment:
After one play you can see how impressive this game is. All of the new players in the initial game foiudn the decisions hard to make because there are many options. The limit of 3 actions per round is hard and in a 4 player game there are only 4 rounds, so 12 actions during the whole game seems so few. But these actions are so cleverly woven that you need to understand the long term implications which you cannot appreciate in your first game.
One of Martin Wallace's best games and may rise to a 10 after more plays.

item.name: Ave
item.comment: The DTP appearance disguises a good game with some interesting systems. Players earn victory points by placing buildings, streets, plazas and mines in Rome. But in order to do so, the senator with the right connections must be influenced to do so. At the same time, Rome is expanding its empire around the Mediterranean through conquest. This is also achieved through influencing the right senators. Clever systems and difficult choices ensure that the game is thought provoking and enjoyable. If a top German company brought a polished version of this out, it would reach the much wider audience that it deserves.

item.name: The Awful Green Things From Outer Space
Axis & Allies Miniatures
item.comment:
Hasbro's answer to Memoir 44 was to make miniatures in a collectable form. While this aspect is the least appealing, as a non painter, the finish on the miniatures is good. My first game was a good introduction. The rules are simply and clearly laid out and easy to read. The examples are consistent with the rules, and the game play is intuitive. The card stock is acceptable but well below German game (Carta Mundi) quality. The overall package is very good and I do not expect my rating to change. The cards themselves contain all the necessary information and this means that they can easily be placed near the units on the board. the minitures even contain a name of the item on the reverse side of the base, which you can read in good light.
The maps are geomorpic and double sided, and when reverse creased flatten down pretty well.
The trading aspect is annoying but a starter and booster will be plenty to play with and at this price the game compares well from a value for money perspective with "standard" boardgames.
I shall add more to to my set on miniatures and look forward to the expansions that will inevitably follow.

item.name: Axis & Allies Naval Miniatures: War at Sea
Balam
item.comment: Ebbs and flows in games are not bad thing, but Balam delivers collosal swings. In my few games so far, at least one person has been a passenger for the last half an hour as the fates have hurt that person. The markets system is clever, while the astromers seem to be critical to voictory or at least not being hit badly by the fate cards.

item.name: Battle Cry
item.comment: Thsi game deserves all the accolades its gets. It has brought wargaming back into the playing zone of German games players. Excellent production, rules, excitement level, feel, simulation, fun, value, replayability, options, variations.

item.name: Battlecards: World Conflict – Pacific Theatre – Starter Set
Battlecards: World Conflict – The Russian Front – Starter Set
Battlecards: World Conflict – Western European Campaign – Starter Set
Before the Wind
item.comment: The best game from the Phalanx stable, this card game has some great mechanisms, such as the selection of cards available for use on a turn. The decisions seem to centre around timing and like all good games you want the game to move quickly as you make progress in the game. Recommended for people who like trading games. Subsequent games of this have confirmed the qulity of the game, as the decisions are difficult to make. My experience after 3 games is that 2 hours might be needed, at least for initial games as the options are pondered by players. None of the people I played with found this a problem. They will all be getting copies once the game is widely available.

item.name: The Best of Dragon Magazine Games
Board and Table Games from Many Civilizations
The BoardGameGeek Game
item.comment:
Playtested a version in March 2009. Put Richard Breese and the BGG brand and you have a great boardgame.
TBGGG has many aspects that you would associate with Richard's games: lots of player interaction, game with definable goals; luck in the form of dice rolling, but with many choices; goals to achieve to maximise your score at the end of the game and the game worked well with 5 and 6 people.
The games quickly in about an hour and there is very little downtime.
Another game to add to the list of can't wait games to come out! It will be one of the games I regularly draw on for 6 players in future years as the player interact

item.name: Boomtown
item.comment: Settl;ers based resource allocation with scoring sets make this a pleasant and less chaotic Bruno F game. Relaxing, with mild moments of challenge ensure a good gaming experience.

item.name: The Bottle Imp
item.comment: Superb trick taking game. Unusual numbers within each of the suits, means you have to know the cards well to win.

item.name: Bounty Hunter: Shootout at the Saloon
Brass
item.comment: Initial impression after one game was that this is an excellent business game at the weightier end of the genre. Many decisions to take and the route to making good future decisions is unclear to me after one game. I was taught the game rather than read the June 2007 rules, but there is alot to take in. An exciting release to look forward to in Essen. Initial rating 8, than could raise to 9.

item.name: A Brief History of the World
Buck Rogers: Battle for the 25th Century Game
Buffy the Vampire Slayer: The Game
California
item.comment: Initial rating after one game. The game presents a series of issues to you - the choice of gold or tiles(something like Atlantic Star); placement on your room mat (a simpler form of Princes of Florence) and some additional targets for you to achieve. Overall feel is a quick game (our 4 player game lasted 40 minutes) and pretty enjoyable.

item.name: Canal Grande
item.comment: Similar feel to San Marco, but with some slightly different tactics. I liked the "you divide, I choose" mechanism that has been retained.

item.name: Canal Mania
item.comment:
First impressions: this is an impressive design with high production values - up to 2006 german standards rather than Ragnar clothmap trademark. The game turns are quick and so the play flows well, with plenty of options and (pleasingly) after one game you can see what you did right and wrong. The game feels (and looks) like a cross between Railway Rivals, Lancashire Rails and Stephenson's Rocket, but has its own personality.
Multiple games later, the game play is smooth and clear: there are short term goals, butpossibly fewer long term goals and how your opponents cooperate or not with you has some bearing on your final points score. Very enjoyable game.

item.name: Cannes: Stars, Scripts and Screens
item.comment: I have only played it with 2 and 3 players, but found it very tactical. The old boys network tile need to be played early in the game to get high scores. I am considering playing both tiles in my next 2 or 3 player game.

item.name: Carcassonne: The Castle
item.comment: Very enjoyable 2 player variant with enough new ideas to make the game feel different from previous versions.

item.name: Catan Dice Game
item.comment: Combination of Settlers and dice doesn't quite hit it off, but a pleasant diversion for 15 to 30 minutes.

item.name: Catan Histories: Settlers of America – Trails to Rails
item.comment: The game looks really good and the new ideas work well. Possibly the best evolution of the Settlers Historical series and one that shows the thought that has gone into making the systems dovetail well.

item.name: Catan Histories: Struggle for Rome
item.comment: Good development of the Settlers franchise with a new twist - movement - to add on the familiar systems.

item.name: Caylus Magna Carta
item.comment: Most of Caylus, but with stripped down castle section and a more varied building section. The game has all the tastes of Caylus, but without the elements that cause the game to be long. I loved this version and can see it becoming more popoular than the original as the playing time is about an hour. An essential purchase.

item.name: Celtic Quest
item.comment: Best of the new series of 2005 JKLM's. Mixes some Magic Realm elements of movement with a range of options for characters, trading and character development and potentially 2 sides (Romans and Celts). These features all work together smoothly and produce a stimulating game.

item.name: China Moon
item.comment: Elephantan Parade with frogs and lilies. At the lighter end of the spectrum and amusing.

item.name: Cleopatra and the Society of Architects
Codeword Cromwell: The German Invasion of England, 8 June 1940
Coloretto
item.comment: The game features some of the aspects of Hattrick, in so far as you acquire cards tat score positively and negatively. It works well with the range indicated, though perhaps more fun with 4 or 5. The extremely simple system means you learn the rules quickly, but the play is compulsive. A very good quick card game that fits in the end of evening slot.

item.name: Colosseum
item.comment: I enjoyed this resoruce gathering game. The translation of resources into points scoring worked well and I enjoyed the theme. The components are up to high DoW statndards, while the only doubt seems to be over the game length as the prelude to the final (possibly decisive) position is the 4 preceding rounds. I'm looking forward to playing this again.

item.name: Combat Commander: Europe
item.comment: Superb interaction of systems generates fantastic excitement!

item.name: Conflict of Heroes: Awakening the Bear! – Russia 1941-42
Conflict of Heroes: Storms of Steel! – Kursk 1943
Constantinopolis
item.comment:
Lots of interesting mechanisms are blended well in this game. Shades of Puerto Rico (roles); resource translation (Key-games); shipping goods (Cuba) and building buying from Puerto Rico/Cuba mean that you have seen all the parts before but not in this combination. The game is engrossing and the routes to earning victory points seem well balanced after a few games.
2nd game - (with 5) was a little long

item.name: Cosmic Encounter
item.comment: My closest game to being an "11". Amazing fun.

item.name: Crocodile Pool Party
item.comment: The game rules suggest this is playable in 20 minutes or so. I'm sure it is, but the puzzles presented by the game were good enough to make my first game last a stimulating 60 minutes. Much deeper that the title may suggest and I enjoyed my first acquantance with the Crocs.

item.name: Darkover
item.comment: If you play a game where you need to duel by looking into a player's eyes, saying "One Darkover", "Two Darkover" "three Darkover" and do not break down into tears of laughter this could be the game for you. My last game of this was in 1978 at college and it is probably best suited to that environment.

item.name: Dead of Winter: A Crossroads Game
Diceland
item.comment: Lotas of strategic options, from the building of the shape of the board, to the placement of key hexes. Bad dice rolls can of course ruin an attck (or defence), but you do know the odds for each attack and therefore the risks. The number of dice rolls in teh game ought to balance the luck out, but of course it won't quite. Many options for attacking and planning the routes to your attacks make this a game far above "just dice rolling".

item.name: Doctor Who: The Game of Time & Space
Dominant Species
item.comment: Initial view is that is brain burner game is incredibly clever. Great systems and options, but needs more games to know how good the game really is, but initial expectations are very good.

item.name: Dungeons & Dragons Dice Masters: Battle for Faerûn
Eclipse
item.comment: Great 4X game with excellent interlocking game systems

item.name: Edo
item.comment:
At first the game appears difficult to get into and while the rules are clear, they are difficult to absorb. But soon they sink in and you see the cleverness in the design.
It's a very good planning game and the situation on the board helps to determine what you do each turn. Very enjoyable and I look forward to more games soon.

item.name: Eketorp
item.comment: The game is good fun for 4 or 5 players as there is little down time, competition for resources and a game that progresses well to its conclusion. The usual dB style components (foam backed pieces) work well in forming the walls.

item.name: Election USA
item.comment: Surprisingly good. Beneath the humour of the cards is a resource management game with some twists along the way and clever mechanisms that make the game more tense and exciting. Not deep like most Martin Wallace games, but you can see his style in the game.

item.name: The End of the Triumvirate
item.comment: Very good three player game; three victory options and the winning conditions seem to mean that each player will be getting to victory conditions together, which makes for an exciting game.

item.name: Escape: The Curse of the Temple
Fettnapf
item.comment: The reliance on memory for this is not as high as it first appears. There are soem simple tactics to use and the game is fun to play making it an ideal end of evening game.

item.name: A Few Acres of Snow
item.comment: One of the best 2 player games on a long while.

item.name: Food Chain Magnate
item.comment:
One of the best (the best?) Splotter games with so much to think about and consider. I loved it. Top 100 prediction.
Advice about starting a run through with no salaries and milestones is a good idea.

item.name: Formula D: Circuits 3 – Singapore & The Docks
Formula Dé Circuits 11 & 12: Watkins Glen & Silverstone
Formula Dé Circuits 13 & 14: Montreal & Long Beach
Formula Dé Circuits 23 - 26: USA Track Pack #1
Formula Dé Circuits 27 - 30: USA Track Pack #2
Formula Dé Circuits 5 & 6: Kyalami & Ferrari Autodromo
Formula Dé Mini
item.comment:
After one game I am really impressed,. The game system allows more flexibility of actions than FD and the game passes much quicker. The intruiging pit stop rules have an element of luck in them, but the prospect of a fast pitstop too. Minor things like the wing and body colours being interchageable and matching with a two part gear marker improve the ease of knowing what gear is used by each car.
The shorter course and simpler corners all add up to making the game more accessible. The worry is that another 20+ board may be produced in this style!

item.name: Fortune and Glory: The Cliffhanger Game
A Game of Thrones: The Board Game (Second Edition)
Glen More
item.comment: The game works, but play is not intuitive. The catch up mechanism of counting -3 points for more tiles so you have to be careful to get enough victory points from the additional tiles. It is an interesting design but you need a couple of games to get the hang of how to play well.

item.name: Gloria Mundi
item.comment: Initial view is that the game is well balanced. you can see short term and medium term goals. There is a possibility of catching up with the leader through cooperation but in my first game all players were close to winning. I liked the use of the building cards and the range of options they present. lots of interaction and decision making, but with three people, the downtime was reasonable.

item.name: Goa
item.comment:
The best new game I have played in 2004. The blending of resources is sublime.
The immediate view of its quality was to compare this game with Puerto Rico and Princes of Florence, both of which it resembles in various ways.
While there is some solitaire planning, you do need to follow what others are doing and the auctions of course do involve all players.
Even after playing this a few times, there appear to be multiple routes to victory, which suggests the game is as promising as it feels.
There is no doubt in my mind that this is a 10 game for me.

item.name: Goal! Game: Germany vs. Czech Republic
GolfProfi
item.comment: After half a dozen games, I am finding this to be the best golf game on the market. The handicapping system is new to me and makes teh game much more addictive.

item.name: Grand Prix: F1
item.comment: The game reminds me of a quicker version of Motorsport. Players are presented with some interesting options each turn, as cards in the hand determine track position. The pit rules work well, as you have to decide how how long to stay for refuelling and what tyres to select. The board contains enough good and bad spaces, that planning is important. This can be blown of by a car causing yo to take a less optimal route.

item.name: La Granja
item.comment: Rating could improve

item.name: Das GROSSE und das kleine A
item.comment: Remarkably good card game that rewards you noting how many cards each play has! I often play with 4 or 5 players and the game works well with this number.

item.name: Guatemala Café
item.comment: Two boarded game with buying on one and placement on the other. I liked the mechanics.

item.name: Guerilla
item.comment: The ultimate 5 player game. Two people are guerillas, two are the government and one is neutral. And this can change during the game! Brilliant game, but best with five.

item.name: Die GulliPiratten: Der Schrecken der Kanalisation
Hamburgum
item.comment:
Played this with four people, one of whom had played before. It was treated as a learning experience and the knowledge picked up from a previous game showed through. The game has many facets, with plenty of control on your own options, short term goals to achieve in terms of game progress and many longer term goals. The player interaction is not extensive, but sufficient that you need to beware of what other players are up to on the board, as well as in the purchase of ships.
My impression is that Hamburgum acheives a great deal in 75 to 90 minutes of entralling gameplay with very little to dislike and much to admire in the clean gameplay. One of the excellent games to come from Essen 2007 and the best use of the clever rondel mechanism. Extremely good game with 4. I will later test with 3 and 5 players I am sure.

item.name: Happy Pigs
item.comment: Surprisingly good. Loads of pigs, several interesting choices and 1 hour game time.

item.name: Hattrick
item.comment: Now played well over 500 times. This is our game of choice for closing an evening. Best with 4 but also good with 5 or 6. Klaus Palesch could not have envisioned what fun he inspired on this game.

item.name: Le Havre
item.comment:
A game that sucks you in. Sometimes you see your game engine develop and then you expand too quickly and you slow down. The range of options is stunning and this becomes boggling to see the woood from the trees. Brilliant brilliant game.
Updated from a 9 in August 2010

item.name: Hawaii
item.comment:
Excellent game from HiG. Plenty of options to consider as you complete your crossword of village (numbers and breadth).
Replay value is good as the tiles are re-ordered for each game and each game round has new challenges presented by changing the value of each area.

item.name: Heart of Africa
item.comment: Clever game with interesting mechanics. The game appears to be thoroughly playtested, but had one or two graphical glicthes. The rules need more clarification about "up" and "down", which are confusingly used in the rules. This does not take away from an excellent game.

item.name: Die heisse Schlacht am kalten Buffet
Die heisse Schlacht am kalten Buffet
The Heroes of Might & Magic IV Collectible Card & Tile Game
Heroscape Master Set: Rise of the Valkyrie
I Go!
item.comment:
Light and easy on the brain, this card game poses sufficient problems to be a decent card game. Decisions as to what to collect, when to take from the tavern and when to declare all make this pleasant card game well worth trying.
Low card finish means that the cards are more flimsy than they should be and you have come to expect from games produced in the last 15 years. But this dos not detract from the value of the game.

item.name: In the Shadow of the Emperor
item.comment: Upgraded rating in the light of game in Feb 2012

item.name: In the Year of the Dragon
Indonesia
item.comment: I played the propotype in July 2005 and was impressed. The game has many of the hallmarks of a Splotter game, but a faster time, far more player interaction and some clever systems. Top of my wish list for Essen 2005. Subsequent plays have confirmed it as a top game with plenty of options and strategies to follow. I really like the swapping of companies and the underlying processes. One of the best games to be produced during 2005/06.

item.name: Industria
item.comment: Very clever game with multiple scoring possibilities. You have to consider the implications of your bids not just on your self but also on others. Definitely a gamer's game and the best game I played at Essen 03.

item.name: Infection: Humanity's Last Gasp
item.comment: Thoroughly enjoyable solitaire game.

item.name: Ingenious: Travel Edition
item.comment: Excellent two player game, which has been superbly packaged. This makes it ideal for travelling and should be an early part of packing for a holiday.

item.name: InterUrban
item.comment: Light railway game with the focus on laying track than financial decisions. The track radiate from a random set up of stations and the trick is deciding when to play your stations and limit other players options. Very enjoyable game after 3 plays. It feels like Transamerica because it is not hard to play and I would not be surprised to see a deluxe version produced in a year's time.

item.name: Isle of Skye: From Chieftain to King
It's Alive!
item.comment: Quick game that plays in 30 minutes. Plenty of decisions, good graphics and theme and good mechanics. This is welcome news as another British publisher gets into the Board games business.

item.name: ITC
item.comment: This is very good economic/business games with plenty of interaction and opportunity to win.

item.name: Jantaris
item.comment: The components do not suggest that the game will be exciting and the board has very few features. Yet the game has several intriging aspects. The interaction between players is good and you have to think about what each player might want from their turn when playing the cards. My initial impression after Essen is positive and I look forward to further games to re-affirm this.

item.name: Jenseits von Theben
item.comment: Polished archeology game where the game and them fit well. Lost of good ideas in the game and one of the special games to come out of Essen 2004. It crept in unannounced and surprised everyone. 2nd edition has slightly revised graphics but the same good gameplay.

item.name: Jockey
item.comment: Always had immense fun in this race game. The uncertainty of who has backed each horse overshadows the actualk outcome of the betting.

item.name: John Silver
item.comment: Clever card game wher you must check what your opponents can pass to you in points as much as what you can gain yourself. Three simultaneous lines are being monitored each turn while you work out whch cards in your hand will do most good to you, harm to your opponents or least good to your opponents. The game plays quickly and there is some planning but it does not seem easy to monitor who is leading. Well liked after early plays.

item.name: Kaivai
item.comment: Despite rules that need a re-write to be easier to read, there is a reasonable game in here. But if the rules are poorly designed, the game needs to be more inituitive so that you can make progress more quickly.

item.name: Key Harvest
item.comment:
Played an ealier version of this about a year ago. It was good then and it will be better since that time. Multi company launch will reduce Key upset people.
Now played the final product and it is much imporved on the earlier playtest version. The options are many in the game and there are plenty of ways in which you can plan for future actions. Probably not as deep as Reef Encounter, but a good gamer's game.

item.name: Key Market
item.comment:
Key Market bears all the signs of a game from R&D, - difficult decisions that are hard to assess, a reasonable playing time (90 minutes), a changing environment, replayability, plenty of ways to make your plans pay off or fail. And now - great graphics.
The game has a different setting for the board each time, so the start is never the same and the clever use of the guild tiles mean that the routes to scoring victory points will always change. It’s a bit like the different options you get from playing Dominion as the changing options are one of the best elements to both games. Then there is the simple, but effective market conditions of resources which come in at different prices each turn, and the whole environment creates a stimulating resource management game.
I have played Key Market in two versions now - an earlier version (Sept 09) which had significant concerns from my view point and the current version which is a polished game (March 10). Definitely one of the best games to get at Essen 2010.
Update Dec 10: The published game is one of the best of 2010, with a tremendous range of options to earn VP's and the changes made each game suggest a better longevity as the options will be different prfrom each previous game. Certainly in my top 5 for 2010.

item.name: Keyflower
item.comment:
Played pre-release version. The familiar Breese traits of multiple options in this Key game are present, but in this game resource cubes are used to upgrade resource hextiles, rather than converted into different cubes. This change from other Key games makes Keyflower have a fresh feel.
The games has 4 rounds each of which present a myriad of options, which means that games will be radically different. Player interaction is high as there is bidding for all hex tiles and you can use other player's tiles as well as your own. The number of choices you have is high and you need an initial game to get the hang of these.
Early days yet but this might be the best Key game.

item.name: Keyflower: The Merchants
item.comment:
I played a playtest version with Richard at our March 2014 Eastbourne gaming weekend and not surprisingly, the expansion adds more interest to a very good gamer's game. The depth addition is that there are more things to consider and therefore more ways to make progress. In my game we played the Merchants without the Farmers (thankfully) as there was enough to consider already.
The additional contract aspects did not lengthen the game much and I am really looking forward to the final version to see how it has developed in the last 6 months. It is an essential addition if you like Keyflower.

item.name: Kings Progress
item.comment: Played with some revisions to the rules, this is nearly very good. The mechanisms interlock pretty well, though the scoring systems are not intuitive. Il Principe achieves a better balance of influence and control of major and minor roles, with a cleaner design.

item.name: Kogge
item.comment: Excellent game with many options each turn. At first they look too daunting, but once you are familiar with the choices they offer many wasy to improve your position. Clever use of markers which have many uses ensures the game board is constantly changing, but in a controlled way. I would think a 2 player game will last about 60 minutes after players become aware of the options.

item.name: Kohle & Kolonie
item.comment: A game that appeals to my tastes. Complex, many things to do but with uncertain pay-offs, lots of indirect interaction and strong on theme. The production values are high, but the rulebook is challenging to learn the game, but once this is overcome, the rich options provide a great gaming experience if you like more involved games.

item.name: Krone & Schwert
item.comment: This is a pleasant game that I found that it played better with 3 than 5 players, as the 5 players each wanted a chance to play the King. Good production and solid mechanisms, but will be in the also rans at the end of the day. The fear of German text on the cards is overdone. There are only a few different types of card and these become recognisable really quickly as they all have a picture.

item.name: Last Night on Earth: The Zombie Game
Last Train to Wensleydale
item.comment:
Final version played at Birmingham Expo 2009
The terrain (mountains and valleys) dictate where the tracks can be laid and the two main railways need to buy your tracks in an interesting and novel system. You need to maintain influence over these two rialwyas, have enough train building acpaity and deal with the Government protesters about rail expansion.
I really liked the need for takeovers, the bidding system for more influence and the use of the different trains to transport passengers and freight. Another clever system from a designer at the height of his powers.

item.name: Lawless
item.comment: Fun game with plenty of atmosphere, but bear in mind the luck of the draw.

item.name: The League: the Football Card Game
Legacy: The Testament of Duke de Crecy
Legendary Encounters: An Alien Deck Building Game
Leonardo & Co: The Amazing Science Quiz
Leonardo da Vinci
item.comment: Early thoughts on this game are very promising. The design weaves a well themed game about inventions with many gamers devices.

item.name: Life is Money
item.comment: Excellent game that deserves a wider reach. The graphics wil not inspire, but the game play and choices will. Any winner from Fanfor that should have the Kosmos/Hans im Gluck treatment that would then guarantee more people play it.

item.name: Lokomotive Werks
item.comment: At first appears to have a low chance of catching the leader. However, after several games now, this is defintely not the case. Firstly the game end mechanisms ensure that the back markers get closer to the game leader and secondly, the game leder may vary considerably throughout the game. The excellent system for creating demand and then obsolence of the different engines is worth the purchase of the game itself.

item.name: London
item.comment: Based on 1 play at UK Expo. The game is fast and has plenty of options each turn. I can see the first game time of 2 hours dropping to 90 minutes when played repeatedly. One of the reasons to go tho Essen 2010.

item.name: Lord of the Rings: Friends & Foes
Lord of the Rings: Sauron
item.comment: More permutations of components to juggle with will allow you to plan the difficulty of the game. You need to have played the basic game to be able to handle the changes, but after an easrly play (without the 23 extra events), we had a very exciting finish. Everyone found that having a bad guy in person added an edge to the game that was missing when he was only represented in the abstract.

item.name: The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game
Lord of the Rings: The Confrontation
item.comment: Clever game of bluff and counter bluff where the powers of the different forces upsets the standard rules. Best played in games of 2 where you switch roles and appreciate how the other half lives.

item.name: Lord of the Rings: The Confrontation (Deluxe Edition)
Lord of the Rings: The Duel
Lords of the Sierra Madre (second edition)
item.comment: A game that is much more about the experience than the game play. Has some great ideas and is strongly themed.

item.name: Lost Cities
item.comment: The ultimate 2 player card game. Plays in 10 minutes, addictive and rewards skilful play, but has a large luck factor too. There are many strategies and these are rewarded via an excellent scoring system. Easy to pass on to non-game players as well as affectionados.

item.name: Lost Worlds Adventure Set I: In the Ruins of the Ancients
Love Letter: Kanai Factory Limited Edition
Mage Knight Board Game
item.comment: Amazing game and one of my favourites of all time and best of 2011.

item.name: Mage Knight Board Game: The Lost Legion
Maharaja: The Game of Palace Building in India
Malefiz
item.comment: Loads of dice rolling, but you feel that tactics come in to as well. Nasty viscious end game situations, and very tense. The double sided board features a circular track, with concentric circles linked at points equidistant around the board. Both boards are fun to play on.

item.name: Los Mampfos
item.comment: Aimed at folks much younger than me. Nice bits and I think I would have liked it alot 45 years ago.

item.name: Manila
item.comment: After one game, this is rated a 6, but could rise to a 7. The options to balance risk and payoffs are present but placing a value on the harbour master is not easy.

item.name: Marvel Dice Masters: Avengers vs. X-Men
Moongha Invaders: Mad Scientists and Atomic Monsters Attack the Earth!
Mü & mehr
item.comment: Mu is one of the great games to play with 5 people. The signalling and card play are excellent and can soon become intuitive. The scoring aspect is less easy to appreciate, but does work well. A masterful card game.

item.name: Mystery Rummy: Al Capone and the Chicago Underworld
item.comment: Beautiful balance in the decisions of which sets to seek, when to play them and when to hold them in your hand. I think the gavel cards are the best set in the Mystery Rummy series (yet).

item.name: Mystery Rummy: Murders in the Rue Morgue
Navegador
item.comment: Very smooth crafted game play for 90 minutes. Possibly the best rondel game?

item.name: Nefertiti
item.comment: Excellent game that has more depth than would appear from the rules. Good mechanisms and clear options mean that the choices are easy to see but difficult to make. Might rise higher with more plays.

item.name: Ninety-Nine
item.comment: An excellent 3 player game. Perhaps the best game for three players? The name is the highest score that is possible and 9 is the theme of the game - nine tricks played over nine rounds, with 9 cards used each round to forecast the bid.

item.name: Nomads of Arabia: The Wandering Herds Game
Nottingham
item.comment:
Interesting card game that flows very well. It is possibloe that the rating might imporve with more plays.
Cards have two options - play the action or retain the card in order to collect sets. Sets are scored in threes or against specific targets, such as two of type A,B and C for points. A neat device is the movement of the Sherrif of Nottingham who moves each time a set is scored and when he reaches the end of his track, the game ends (one of two ways to do so). On each track of his path is a number, which is indicates whether you can get an extra card by having this number of cards or fewer in your hand. It is intersteing as it can help you gain cards at good times and you need to consider this when you are scoring hands. Enjoyable game.

item.name: Oasis
item.comment:
My initial play was excellent. The mechanics work really well and make for a tightly balanced game. Players can haul themselves up from last to first position in the card offerings and improve their game posistion as a result. Very enjoyable and clever.
Subsequent plays have raised my view. This is so clever and likely to be a game that is played in a year's time.

item.name: Origins: How We Became Human
item.comment: First game, provisional view is a 9 rating. The mechanics take some while to learn and the rulebook works rather is very clear at explaining. The concepts need some time to sink in and then there is a desire to make progress. This means learning how the different engines in the game interact and how you overcome the game barriers to make quicker progress. But the urge to move forward in the game is strong and this is why the game is exciting to play.

item.name: Outreach: The Conquest of the Galaxy, 3000AD
Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Rise of the Runelords – Base Set
Peg Poker
item.comment: I found the inventor, Mr Ted Wheeler, selling it to shops in New Orleans and wanted to get one. He duly obliged and I have a very good game that works well with 3 players. The card dice only have 4 visible sides - the top and bottom are rounded to make the dice roll better. Neat game.

item.name: The Penguin Ultimatum
item.comment: My first game was a three player one and worked well. The placement rules are clever, the cards are well designed and the scoring is easy enough to see. All three players thought the game was good and would play again.

item.name: The Pillars of the Earth
item.comment: Any game that gives you difficult decicions to reach but enjoyable ones at the same time has something going for it and Saulen delivers on both counts.

item.name: The Pillars of the Earth: Builders Duel
The Pillars of the Earth: Expansion Set
The Pillars of the Earth: New Craftsmen
Piracy
item.comment: This is probably the best "pure" pirate game for me to date (March 08). It has a board covering the Carribean (good). Ships can be upgraded in traditional fashion - guns,crew,hold. You can raid treasure fleets and towns, hide out and bury treasure. It provides plenty of atmosphere, which is necessary for a good pirate game, but the production values mean the hexes are slightly smaller than they need be and perhaps there is a touch too much dependency on luck.

item.name: Pirate Dice: Voyage on the Rolling Seas
Pirate's Cove
item.comment: I found the additional quality of product in the Days of Wonder version, plus the changes in rules improved the game and the enjoyment level.

item.name: Polis: Fight for the Hegemony
item.comment: Amazing game.

item.name: Power Grid
item.comment: Having played the game with a variety of people and numbers, I have changed my earlier views. The game is tight with tough decisions throughout. Excellent game that just needs a Hans im Gluck touch to improve the components.

item.name: The Prince: The Struggle of House Borgia
The Princes of Florence
item.comment: Having played this game over a span of 10 years, it stands the test of time. A really superb design.

item.name: Princes of the Renaissance
item.comment: Early comments after one game: There are multiple roads to victory, multiple alliances and some cunning ways to screw your opponents. Very enjoyable, but the first game is a major learning exercise in what is possible. Subsequent plays have upgraded the rating. With the intrigue, back stabbing and dirty tricks the games gets even better!

item.name: Prophecy
item.comment: Long but engaging fantasy trip

item.name: Puerto Rico
item.comment: Similar in feel and pace to Princes of Florence. Many options to score victory points and this makes the game replayable. Less direct interaction - more interaction by choice of the roles. Excellent game that will be popular with Princes of Florence fans.

item.name: Puerto Rico: Expansion I – New Buildings
Race! Formula 90
item.comment: Interesting mix of options, even in the basic game. The robots are well handled and provide the right level of interference.

item.name: Railways of the World: The Card Game
The Really Nasty Horse Racing Game
Reef Encounter
item.comment: I have playtested the game several times and it is a clever game with systems and options that are not immediately intuitive. The final version looks really good and I expect to play this many times.

item.name: Rise and Decline of the Third Reich
Robinson Crusoe: Adventures on the Cursed Island
Roll Through the Ages: The Bronze Age
item.comment: We play with revised scoring to allow for a slightly longer game. 4 player games now last 40 minutes

item.name: Roll Through the Ages: The Iron Age
Roll Through the Ages: The Iron Age with Mediterranean Expansion
Roll Through the Ages: The Late Bronze Age
Russian Railroads
item.comment: Excellent worker placement game with a myriad of choices that are clear to see but difficult to choose from.

item.name: San Juan
item.comment: Puerto Rico's baby brother comes good. The cards dictate your options, but within these there are many choices to make. The roles remain at the heart of the game and the new role is enjoyable and appropriate for the new game. The cards have multiple uses, and this adds to the confusion and difficulty but after a few games they quickly become clear. The speed of the game is really good - hardly any downtime as the multiple options are considered and the use of cards means that the atmosphere is much more relaxed than PR. This will attract more people to play San Juan, while a few who relish the control within PR may be put off. Overall rating after 5 games is excellent.

item.name: Die Schlacht der Dinosaurier
item.comment: Amazing fun, loads of laughs and wonderful 3D creatures. Great system for resolving hits and always a pleasure to play.

item.name: Senjutsu: Dynamic Samurai Combat
item.comment: After 2 plays of the game, I am impressed. The components work well together and there are a wide number of strategies to follow. Chess like because you have to think of the possibilities; Stratego like because the opponent's strength is not shown to you, so this blend presents some interesting possibilities for each turn. The cards that are picked up for eliminating an opponent's piece provide a potential twist to each move.

item.name: Sergeants Miniatures Game: Day of Days
The Settlers of the Stone Age
item.comment: Some interesting ideas based on the original Settlers premise, so if you like the original, you'll like this.

item.name: Shadows of Brimstone: City of the Ancients
Shadows of Brimstone: Swamps of Death
Sid Meier's Civilization: The Board Game
Sid Meier's Civilization: The Board Game – Fame and Fortune
item.comment: Expected expansion, but with more in than I was hoping for, so this is a game I am excited to see.

item.name: Sid Meier's Civilization: The Card Game
Die Siedler von Catan: Das Buch zum Spielen
Die Siedler von Catan: Das Turnier-Set zum Kartenspiel
Die Siedler von Catan: Historische Szenarien
Die Siedler von Catan: Historische Szenarien II
Die Siedler von Catan: Kartenspiel – Handel & Wandel
Die Siedler von Catan: Kartenspiel – Ritter & Händler
Singapore
item.comment: Solid cube conversion game to maximise VP's. Much depends on the location of tiles and how you spot good routes. The early loss of money and points might appear devastating, but this is compensated for by the ability to place opponents building tiles in expensive locations.

item.name: Spartacus: A Game of Blood & Treachery
Star Trek: Customizable Card Game (first edition)
Star Trek: Fleet Captains
item.comment: Initial impression, which might rise with more plays. Sub standard components prevent a higher rating.

item.name: Star Trek: Fleet Captains – Romulan Empire
Star Trek: The Next Generation Collectible Dice Game
Starship Merchants
item.comment: Rating will rise once clarification of rules allows a game to be played correctly. The printed set has too many areas of uncertainty and the FAQ and card clarifications need to be read before play.

item.name: Steam
item.comment:
Steam in its basic form is the excellent train game that combines all the good elements of Age of Steam and overcomes all the bits that don't work quite so well in Age of Steam.
For example: the replenishment of resources to a city can now arrive in a package with some choices and not disrupt the game with luck; the turn order is predefined by previous choices rather than a bidding war; and you take loans out when you need then rather than planning for a potential eventuality. And all this works to streamline the game and make an already good game even more playable. Magnificent.

item.name: Steel Driver
item.comment: Exceptionally good game that belies the simple options you have. Works well with 6 players.

item.name: Stock Car Championship Racing Card Game
Stone Age
item.comment: Solid game which provides plenty of options. Probably it is a game to take Euro beginners onto once they have exhausted Settlers, TTR and Carcasonne.

item.name: Street Illegal
item.comment: I like the overtaking rules and the control you have over your car, its speed and the planning to meet the track conditions. Early games have been very enjoyable.

item.name: Struggle of Empires
item.comment: After one playing. This was a great gaming experience, that all players in my group enjoyed. The alliance system is very clever and sets the tone of the game. Lots of Wallace historical game trademarks make this a tremendous game.

item.name: Subulata
item.comment: Interesting 2 player game that has decpetive strategies. The random board set up and placement of your subulata ensure great replay potential. I really enjoyed my first game.

item.name: Tahuantinsuyu
item.comment: Clever systems of balance ensure that the leader can be caught in a short time. Timing of options that are available through the Sun cards is crucial. Well balanced game with many routes to scoring victory points within a scripted sequence of play. The game system is well contructed and the components are reasonable.

item.name: Take it Easy!
item.comment: Teachable to non regular gamers in minutes, and very playable. I've sold loads of copies on this basis and will sell more in the future.

item.name: Take Two
item.comment: Clever word game that demands fast thinking!

item.name: Through the Ages: A Story of Civilization
item.comment: Wonderful game with a glttering array of things to do each turn. One of the games where you cannot wait for your turn to come around again.

item.name: Through the Ages: A Story of Civilization
Ticket to Ride
item.comment: Transamerica with more choices and twists. Wonderful game.

item.name: Ticket to Ride Map Collection: Volume 2 – India & Switzerland
Ticket to Ride: Europe
item.comment: Better and tighter than the original

item.name: Ticket to Ride: The Card Game
Time is Money
item.comment: Light and enjoyable. The timer is useful for this and other games. useful as a filler.

item.name: Time War
item.comment: The one game in my collection that I will not go back in time and replay.

item.name: Tori
item.comment: Clever trading game that has more to it than you realise,

item.name: Trains
item.comment:
Dominion style game gets a major lift in theme by adding railways and a board to build your rails.
My first two games (played straight after each other) used two of the recommended set ups and they worked really well. With 30 sets of cards to use and only 8 per game, the combinations are wide.
Great fun, speedy turns and sufficient planning options to make the game have enough meat in to satisfy me.

item.name: TurfMaster
item.comment: Really feels like racing and with the expansion, there are some extra great courses to vary play.

item.name: Turning Point: Stalingrad
item.comment: Fun game with lots going on and plenty of luck.

item.name: Tuscany: Expand the World of Viticulture
Ubongo
item.comment: An appreciation of tangram solving and ability to do this against the clock are prerequisites, so choose your gaming partners well. Has the ability to be played by families and plays in 30 minutes.

item.name: Urbania
item.comment:
Beautifully produced cards. Balancing decisions around when to buy cards with money and those with workers looks to be interesting. And when to get the goal cards is another good decision to consider.
It is hard to distinguish which building tiles are available to develop from those that are not.
My rating could increase with more plays.

item.name: Vegas
item.comment: Fun and easy to play with a good balance of decision making and luck. Great set up means that each round will be different and it is all over in 20 minutes.

item.name: Vegas Showdown
item.comment: Nothing sparklingly original, but the package provided does work and the mix of resource goals is not straightforward to achieve. All the components were good except the players "boards" which were of paper. the nmechanics intermixed well land the rules were pretty clear.

item.name: VOC! Founding the Dutch East Indies Company
Where There Is Discord: War in the South Atlantic
Wildcatters
item.comment: Initial impression is of a well crafted oil production and delivery game with some clever systems. Lots going on and to consider, so the subtleties of play may only be revealed a few games in.

item.name: Wizard In Training Trading Card Game
Xia: Legends of a Drift System
item.comment: Updated rating to a 9 as much more magic of the game is revealed. Rating could improve further.

item.name: Yspahan
item.comment: Excellent medium weight game that plays in an hour. The blend of options to consider. Cards a powerful and always beneficial. Well worth getting if you have not got it.

item.name: Zing!
item.comment: Clever twist on estimation whist that will get many plays.

item.name: Zooloretto
item.comment: My first game with 5 played very well. Not surprisingly Coloretto players will be famiailar with teh choices as this is strongly based on Coloretto. The additional dimension is placement and this makes teh game worth purchasing as there are a few more options to consider.
